bioghist.p: Joseph Trimble Rothrock (1839-1922), physician, botanist, forester, was born in McVeytown, Mifflin County, Pa. He graduated from Harvard University in 1864 with a degree in botany, having studied under Asa Gray and Louis Agassiz. He studied medicine with his father, Dr. Abraham Rothrock, later earning his M.D. from U. of Pennsylvania in 1868. In that same year, Rothrock became professor of botany at Pennsylvania State Agricutlrual College. In 1873 he joined the Wheeler survey as botanist and surgeon. From 1877 to 1904, he was professor of botany at the U. of Pennsylvania. An opportunity to study botany at the U. of Strassburg left him much impressed with German forest conservation policies. He was one of the founders of the Pennsylvania Forestry Association and its president by 1886. Govenor Pattison appointed Rothrock to a commission to study the state's forests in 1893, and in 1901 Rothrock was appointed the first commissioner of the newly created state forestry department.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of approximately 3,000 letters as well as other manuscripts of Rothrock's lectures on botany and forestry, published articles, scrapbooks, diaries, newspaper clippings and photographs. Correspondence includes family letters as well as letters related to his involvement in Pennsylvania forestry.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
